p.ref: The Fortitude of the North under the Disaster of the Second Manassas
p.note: Note 3: [Historical] General Robert E. Lee and the Army of Northern Virginia defeated General John Pope’s Union Army of Virginia in the Second Manassas. (Christina Lee)

body.p:
They take no shame for dark defeat While prizing yet each victory won, Who fight for the RightNote 2: [Critical][Intratextual] This poem, along with the previous poem ”Inscription" focuses on Right and Cause, part of “a constellation of values associated with Law in Melville’s mind” (Shurr 17). (Christina Lee) through all retreat, Nor pause until their work is done. The Cape-of-StormsNote 1: [Historical] There is disagreement about which Cape “Cape-of-Storms” refers to. Cohen suggests that “Cape-of-Storms” refers to Cape Horn since “[f]or Melville Cape Horn is often a symbol of anguish and trial” and he points to references in Melville’s letters, journal entries and White-Jacket (Cohen 206-207, 280); more recently, however, Monteiro argues that “Cape-of-Storms” refers to Cape of Good Hope, which was originally named Cape of Storms and points to references in Moby-Dick and White-Jacket (Monteiro 55). (Christina Lee) is proof to every throe; Vainly against that foreland beat Wild winds aloft and wilder waves below: The black cliffs gleam through rents in sleet When the livid AntarcticThe area surrounding Antarctica.
[reference, geography] storm-clouds glow.
